Week 1
Week 2

Week 4

Week 7
Week 8
Week 9
Week 10
Week 11
Week 12
Classic Text
What is a classic? How is Detroit a classic text?
Riot or rebellion? The Kerner Report sees two unequal societies
Urban renewal projects
How does it hold up? Megastructures v. Heidelberg Project
City Typologies
How North American cities differ from other global cities
Early modern city typologies and how they change
Expansion of the bureaurcratic city
Cities redefined by suburbs, highways, and sprawl
Over 100 US cities rise up--poor, disinvested cities surrounded by wealthy suburbs accessible by car
Decentralized city, unequal access to resources and political power, urban renewal projects
Urban renewal, renaisssance, placelessness, Megastructures v. Heidelberg Project
Modernity
What is modernity? Emerges from the Enlightenment
Captain Jack as a modern individual
The Constitution and Democratic Social Space as examples of modernity
Imbuded with anxiety and detachment after WWI
Indvidual v. Communal solutions for the city, Chaplin v. Rivera
Individual self-sufficiency not paying off for African Americans
Secular capitalist democracies will win WW2, expansion of rational bureaucracy in cities
Distinction between garden suburbs and postwar ones: individuality, meritocracy, capitalism, privacy, but also anxiety about the Cold War, bomb
Individual meritocracy, capitalism only benefitting the few at the expense of the many
Myth of suburbs as individual private, and self-reliant when they are still reliant on city/public resources
Megastructures (Neo-Liberalism), Heidleberg Project (individualism, diversity, meritocracy)
"Frontier"
What does the frontier mean within American culture?
Ways of Seeing the "Frontier" in North America, Detroit
Toqueville finds frontier that is not really wilderness, African Americans and new immigrants in new cities
New wealth and opportunities in city
Ford Manual as guide to this new industrialized frontier, Chaplin sees nothing new, Rivera the prospect for unity
Blacks moving into white neighbourhoods and the possibility of integrated urban spaces
U.S. wins war against fascism, emerges as the new world power
Suburbs as a new frontier
Burn it down, create something new (based on Black Power), a new frontier?
New frontier is decentralized cities, Is this Chaplin leaving? Walking away from Omelas?
Edge cities, Different ways of seeing frontier? Moving back to city among young, gentrifying as the new frontier
John Berger
Berger's argument about links to the past
Europeans try to break from the past by settling in North America
Different groups breaking from, living in, or living with the past?
Implications of breaking from past for Gatsby
Chaplin sees a break with the past, Rivera wants to live with the past
Blacks try to break from past with social mobility, but are often prevented from doing so
Break from past by winning the war, democracy, new gender roles, seems to be good, but implications
Middle-class whites break from the city and a painful past for a futurama free of crime, non-whites, means of fighting bomb fears
Blacks cannot forget the past, there are implications for trying to forget, the Kerner report "reminds" whites, but ultimately fails
Attempt to break further from past in decade of malaise, neo-lib revolution attempts further, walk away from Omelas?
Younger people who move to the city want to remember the past, megastructures attempt to break, though Renaissance Center also a form of memory
Active Agent
Create a more promising future than the painful past
Suburban layout and exclusivity maps race, gender, family
Racial oppression seen as city falls apart
Urban form shapes racial, class, to some extent gender divisions, urban renewal projects
Buildings for conducting business only, Heidelberg Project includes everyone
Designer People
Modernity creates freedom and a break from the  past (for some)
Examples in Toqueville, created Constitution, African Americans and new immigrants try to build new lives
Wealth and opportunities allow people to re-make themselves
Chaplin: leave the city and break free; Rivera: create a new unified city with room for all
The Sweets and other African Americans try to create new lives, but are prevented
Winning war, chasing a "futurama," women's identities shift
Suburban people making new life, what Chaplin wanted?
Thoughtless violence (riot) or attempt to define a designer people (rebellion)?
City Peripheral remade as leaving the 60s behind, Black Power communities without support, women's liberation movement
Both are kind of designer! One focuses on individualism and capitalism, the other on communal art
Democratic Social Space
What is democratic social space? Does it work? Is it a basis for U.S. cities?
In Constitution, Does with work with new immigrants and migrants to cities?
How  growing wealth affects this concept
How does Fordism affect this concept? Rivera would like to reform, Chaplin to focus on individuality
How do Black Bottom and segregated white neighbourhoods fit in?
Racial housing issues, shifting gendered spaces, 1949 mayoral election based on race and housing
Do suburbs and highways support this concept?
Uprisings as a reaction to being left out and oppressed; Rivera's dream not allowed because of racism and policy, Kerner Report identifies failure
How does this operate when racial and economic divides exist? Gendered spaces blurring, Urban renewal projects
Do Megastructures or the Heidelberg Project represent democratic social space?
Forgetting Machine
North American settlements break from European past
Toqueville's "New Americans," migrants and immigrants try to build new lives
People like Gatsby try to forget poor and rural pasts
Rivera may see the city as a remembering machine!
African American migrants want to use city to forget racial injustice, but unable
Forget the Depression by winning the war, raming up factories, promoting unity
Move to suburbs, try to forget war, crime, fear of bomb
NO, memory of wrongs and attempts to reverse
City Peripheral tries to forget the city even exists, or responsibility to it
City seen as more of a memory machine!
Abandoned Difference
Does everyone abandon differences equally?  Creation of mass culture
What unites people is city experiences
Celebrated in Ford's "Melting Pot" ceremonies
Race shapes who can abandon their differences in helpful ways
Migration from across the country to work in factories, but housing issues prevent unity
Suburbanites from different backgrounds "become" white, part of "imagined" middle class, reinforces white middle class and decentralizes others
Does not exist here--Kerner points out distinctions
Not among different races, classes, ages
Mass/Urban Culture
Mass culture based on the city, reaches people who live outside of cities
Workers partake in the same city-based cultural pursuits despite different backgrounds
Working-class and black migrants add new dimensions to urban mass culture
People move during the war, create common urbanized culture
Urban culture through rock and roll,  movies, TV moves to suburbs
Motown as urban culture even as middle class whites flee
Shift to suburbs, but new urban culture, hip-hop, etc.
Gentrified culture of youth  based in urban identification
Batman Conundrum
People are drawn to the city, but they miss parts of their rural pasts
Chaplin and many other new city dwellers may long for life outside the city
Suburbanites still miss elements of the city, revealed through culture
Fear of the city among outsiders increases, though most of white flight is already complete
People in the City Peripheral miss the city, loss of culture, sense of homogeneity in peripheral
Longing for city due to placelessness, homogenity
City Beautiful v. City Profitable
Beautiful spaces for public use vie with profitable spaces for private use (skyscrapers)
Chaplin: City Profitable is harmful to individuality; Rivera: They may be combined to everyone's benefit
Housing segregation is profitable for real estate, banks, and the government
City Profitable, expansion of bureaucracy, to win the war
Suburbs are profitable and largely homogenous
Areas deemed unprofitable are left by the city and investors to people's detriment
Generally homogenous, meant for profit, urban renewal projects
Heildeberg Project v. Megastructures
Producer v. Consumer
Ford's 5$ Day supports both economies
Suburbs, "Northland" based on consumerism
Production moves to non-union areas or out of country, based on consumerism
Produce art in a consumerist culture
Creative Destruction
Part of the City Profitable, consumerism at the expense of production
Unity v. Uniformity
Chaplin sees city as enforcing a harmful uniformity; Rivera sees it as possibly urging a unifying community
Focus on unity to win the war, but race riots in housing projects and mayoral election reveal uniformity
Uniformity--suburban houses look the same, often homogenous, is this what Chaplin wanted? Fight Cold War with uniformity rather than WW2 unity
Both seem to fall apart, though attempts at unity among Black Power advocates and the Kerner Report fail
Uniformity in decentralized suburbs
Megastructures, placelessness of cities are more uniform, Heidelberg Project promotes unity among neighbourhoods, as Rivera wanted?
Cumulative Causation
Reasons for creation, protection, and reproduction of segregated space, 1920s-1940s
Depopulation, deinvestment, deindustrialization, housing, police brutality, suburbs at expense of city
Futurama
Living durin the Depression, but the future is friendly, technology will help lead better lives
Not the gleaming city, have to leave to prosper
Builds on 1935! Technological advancements in the 21st century city
Lonely Crowd
No unity, fear of others, homogenity, everyone is "Designer" in the same way
Detachment from community and city, walk away from Omelas
Homogenity, detachment
City Peripheral
Expansion of suburbs, decentralization of political and economic power, public support of private investment, gendered blurring after women's liberation movements
Placelessness, Edge Cities
